availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p:
Dabney Kentucky Sept. 4th 1861
To his Excellency Beriah Magoffin
Govenor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky

Your Petitioner would humbly Represent that at the sept. Term of the There was a Joint Inditement against Pulaski Circuit Court in 1860James Doolin & L. D. Garner upon which they were fined $20. Each for retailing ^spiritous Liquor^ by the Quart being Merchants engaged in the sale of goods, wars, and Merchandise, we honestly believed we had a Right to sell by the Quart- to have it taken off and not drank near the Premicis which was done.- at no time has Either of us violated the Laws of our country Except in that instance which was ignorantly done. on Oct. 2nd 1860 We petitioned your Excellency to Remit said fine
By petition including the within statements sworen to and cirtified by J. E. Cossin J. P. of Pulaski County with a great many of the best citizens in this county signed said Petition believing that it would be right for your Elcellency to remit sd fine -- upon which your Excellency done us the Acknouledged favor.- to enter a Respite for Twelve months -- for that portion going to the Commonwealth -- since then L. D. Garner has gone to the State of Tennissee and I am told that I am responsible for the whole fine. which will soon be Due I again humbly petition your Excellency to remit said fine believing as all your humble petitioners did. in my former petition that it would be right for your Excellency to remit said fine
Especialy at such times as this, when we can not get money to pay our Taxes, if we cannot hold a Nutral position and are forced to pay for Prosicuting- (as I think) and unjust Ware. --

Pulaski Cir. Ct
$20 each } Liquor
Jas Doolin & L. D. Garner
Respd 12 Mos
Issd Sept 10th 1861
